answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Joshua,
While I was uable to find many journal articles or books that would answer your question, I have been able to get a few primary documents and other articles related to your topic. 
To begin, San Mateo County, CA recently updated their reserves policy, and while doing so conducted a survey of the policies in 18 counties and 5 cities in California. This document not only describes the policy they approved, but also the statistics from all the other jurisdictions they surveyed.
http://bit.ly/gHzUs5 
In 2005, Yukon, Oklahoma was nominated for one of the ICMA Annual Awards for their public service/reserve fund sales tax. This program established a ¾ penny sales tax to fund an increase in employee salaries and a ¼ penny sales tax increase for the reserve fund. 
http://bit.ly/gNnzpG 
Additionally, I was able to locate an article called “Benchmarking and Municipal Reserve Funds: Theory Versus Practice,” that seems to at least offer some good information. I am not entirely sure what direction you plan on taking your research, so hopefully it is applicable.
http://1.usa.gov/gSyyNV 
I hope these links are helpful in getting started on your research!
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org

text:
I am working on my senior undergrad research seminar and choose to reasearch rainy day/contingency funds.  In particular I am looking at what practices cities and counties use for saving and what constitues their use.  I was wondering if there are any good journal articles or books anyone has read related to this topic.
Thank you,
Josh Brown
